Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: In Situ Borehole Measurements To Partition The Velocity Of The Greenland Ice Sheet Into Ice Deformation And Basal Sliding Components
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sliding of an ice mass along its basal boundary is a fundamental component of motion where bed conditions are wet. Estimates of basal sliding generally result from an inverse analysis of observed surface motion using a model assuming Glen?s generalized constitutive law for isotropic ice. Evidence suggests that this law does not adequately represent ice deformation, due to a variety of issues including ice thermal variations, preferred fabric, and chemical impurities in the ice. The PIs propose an innovative experimental design to improve our understanding of the ice deformation and sliding. A grid of 9 boreholes, each approximately 750 m in depth and extending to the bed, will be drilled through the Greenland Ice Sheet and instrumented with more than 675 sensors to observe ice temperature, ice deformation, and basal sliding. Analysis of the resulting data set will yield the full 3D velocity field and full stress and strain rate tensors for a 420x106 m3 block of ice. The results will be used to assess and improve the constitutive law and will provide a data set for testing inversion methodologies.

The Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets contain enough water to cause massive inundation of heavily populated coastal regions and associated infrastructure, if they were to degrade significantly through melting or delivery of icebergs to the coastal ocean. Our ability to predict future sea level rise is hampered by an inability to accurately model glacier dynamics that connect these ice sheets to the ocean. This project will provide data sets and consequent insight into processes that will lead to improved models of glacier dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motion of the Greenland Ice Sheet results from internal flow (deformation) of the ice mass, and sliding of the ice mass along its basal boundary. The motion at the ice surface results from the combination of the two processes, but scientists have limited ability to partition the surface motion into the two mechanisms, because deformation and sliding processes are not well enough understood.

This project addressed this problem by making direct measurements of sliding and deformation processes within the Greenland Ice Sheet in order to isolate the deformation and sliding components of ice sheet motion. The research focused on detailed measurements of a large block of ice with dimensions of approximately 700x700x700 meters. The surface movement was measured by high precision GPS. Measurements at the base of the ice, and within the ice itself, were made in nine boreholes drilled through the block. Data were collected for two full years. The results constrain the physical conditions at the ice/bed boundary where sliding motion occurs, the amount and the pressure of water at the base that acts to facilitate sliding motion, and the temperature of ice which governs the rate of ice deformation.

The bed of the study block was determined to be bedrock with a relatively thin covering of sediment. This indicates that water at the base of the ice flows along an ice/rock interface. The pressure of the water at this interface has spatial gradients related the dynamics of the drainage system, in addition to mechanical squeezing from the ice. There are occasionally very short lived but high magnitude pulses in water pressure, but these are a localized phenomenon. These factors cause the sliding speed to vary substantially in both time and space. Temperature gradients within the ice imply that vertical ice flow is highly variable over sub-ice-thickness length scales, which in turn generates contrasts in ice temperature that may impact rates of ice deformation and the location of fractures.

This project resulted in scientific outreach to the general public through interviews and profiles in national and international television, print, and radio media. Local outreach to grade school children was conducted at a science center by graduate students, as well as lectures to High School science students by one of the PIs. The project provided a total of 24 student field research experiences, and resulted in two Ph.D. and three M.S. degrees, and the training of two postdoctoral fellows. The findings were used to advise several European organizations tasked with safe storage of nuclear waste in deep geologic repositories, concerning the possible impacts of future glaciations at the storage sites.
